ygData.subject: Re: Some thoughts about EC and natural evolution
ygData.msgSnippet: This is still not the right approach. How do these individuals get their energy? Do they complexify and speciate? There is another point. It is not necessary

This is still not the right approach. How do these individuals get 
their e=
nergy? Do they complexify and speciate? 
There is another point. It is not =
necessary to crossover. 
Well, I wasn't thinking about NNs in particular, b=
ut CPPNs. The 
neural networks do share many things with CPPNs, but I consi=
der them 
as brains in organisms with fixed topology. This is still the sam=
e 
thing! The environment is limited and they cannot go out of the box. 
Fo=
r example, consider the evolution of autonomous cars. No matter how 
smart =
they are getting, they are still cars, but in the case of 
natural evolutio=
n they can turn into planes! 
What about changing the entire concept? What =
if CPPN-based 
individuals exist in a virtual environment where their survi=
val 
(selection) is depending on nothing but themselves? Picbreeder is a 
p=
erfect example for this. In order to understand what I mean, please 
think =
of those images as they were selected without human 
interaction. Assume th=
at the environment is not the artist's 
perception, but some kind of.. real=
 environment.. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Miguel" <ces=
argm@...> wrote:
>
> I think this is usually investigated under the name of=
 Complex
> Evolutionary Systems.
> 
> Some genetic-based simulations do not=
 use that same "generation" 
cycle
> we usually have in GAs. Individuals ma=
y reproduce with some
> probability when they "meet" and have enough energy=
 to do so. Also,
> the population can increase/decrease arbitrarily. Indivi=
duals die 
when
> their energy is below a certain threshold so there's not =
"direct"
> selection mechanism.
> 
> I've been thinking how that would work=
 with a population of
> ANN-controlled organisms living in a 2D environment=
 and borrowing 
some
> ideas from NEAT, like the genetic encoding method an=
d the crossover
> and mutation operators.
> 
> There were some approaches l=
ike these in the past (before NEAT) but
> most of them don't highlight the =
differences between the standard GA
> and such complex system simulation.
>=
 
> I know this message has little to do with picbreeder, but Petar's
> poi=
nts motivated to write :-)
> 
> Cesar
> 
> On 8/13/07, petar_chervenski <pe=
tar_chervenski@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > As I wrote that answ=
er, I started thinking on how to create 
unguided
> >  evolution in compute=
rs based on the principles of NEAT. This is a
> >  very complex problem. Th=
e problem is not that every GA is 
evolving to
> >  a predefined target and=
 easily skips promising genomes. The 
problem
> >  is the difference betwee=
n the GAs and nature. In nature, there 
is no
> >  somebody like God who sa=
ys "You're good and you deserve to mate, 
and
> >  you will die". The organ=
isms are choosing their mates. So, a very
> >  good genome will not survive=
 just because its phenotype can eat 
a lot
> >  or live longer.. In fact, t=
he phenotypes themselves tell which is
> >  good, very indirectly. This kin=
d of indirection need to be
> >  abstracted. If we want to achieve a lot of=
 complexity that was 
never
> >  discovered by humans, we have to give the =
individuals the power 
of...
> >  Say, it's like democracy in human society=
.
> >  What I see in Picbreeder and IEC at all, is that the human takes 
th=
e
> >  role of each indivudual, when he sees one. As I run my view 
through=

> >  these 15 images, for each one I am thinking of the image as it 
was
>=
 >  me. I say "I'm looking fine!", or "Oh, I'm so ugly!".
> >  So, the way =
to automate this kind of process is to find a way to 
let
> >  the individu=
als express themselves. The human designer sets up 
the
> >  environment, o=
f course, but everything else should happen
> >  automatically. The selecti=
on method must be very very different 
than
> >  the usual, I guess.
> >  H=
ow we can put this into something practical? I have some
> >  suggestions, =
but it turns out to be a kind of Alife stuff. Well, 
I
> >  cannot even exp=
ress myself! :)
> >  Does somebody have any ideas?
> >
> >  Peter
